definition:
A *cyclotomic field* (or *cyclotomic number field*) is a cyclotomic
extension of $\mathbb{Q}$. These are all of the form
$\mathbb{Q}(\omega_n)$, where $\omega_n$ is a .

The ring of integers of a cyclotomic field always has a . Specifically,
the ring of integers of $\mathbb{Q}(\omega_n)$ is
$\mathbb{Z}[\omega_n]$.

Given a $\omega_n$, its minimal polynomial over $\mathbb{Q}$ is the
cyclotomic polynomial $\Phi_n(x)$. Thus,
$[\mathbb{Q}(\omega_n)\!:\!\mathbb{Q}]=\varphi(n)$, where $\varphi$
denotes the Euler phi function.

If $n$ is odd, then $\mathbb{Q}(\omega_{2n})=\mathbb{Q}(\omega_n)$.
There are many ways to prove this, but the following is a relatively
short proof: Since
$\omega_n={\omega_{2n}}^2\in \mathbb{Q}(\omega_{2n})$, we have that
$\mathbb{Q}(\omega_n)\subseteq\mathbb{Q}(\omega_{2n})$. We also have
that
$[\mathbb{Q}(\omega_{2n})\!:\!\mathbb{Q}]=\varphi(2n)=\varphi(2)\varphi(n)=\varphi(n)=[\mathbb{Q}(\omega_n)\!:\!\mathbb{Q}]$.
Thus, $[\mathbb{Q}(\omega_{2n})\!:\!\mathbb{Q}(\omega_n)]=1$. It follows
that $\mathbb{Q}(\omega_{2n})=\mathbb{Q}(\omega_n)$.

**Note.** If $n$ is a positive integer and $m$ is an integer such that
$\gcd(m,n)=1$, then $\omega_n$ and ${\omega_n}^m$ are the same
cyclotomic field.
